caption_text: A representative calculation is shown in Fig. 1 for a reactor operated at 925 F (769.26 K), 200 psig (14.8 bar), and 5.0 WHSV with n-heptane fed and 5.0 mol/mol hydrogen dilution. The simulation is done with 105 algebraic equations and 7 differential equations. Fig. 2 gives selected intraparticle profiles at the reactor inlet, and shows that transport effects are significant at these conditions.

caption_text: STEWAJtT Al4 REACTOR SIMULATION AND PARAMETER ESTIMATION The forward rate coefficients k3(T) and equilibrium coefficients K (T) in Table 1 are represented by the Arrhenius and van t Hoff equations, respectively; the temperature dependence of the adsorption coefficients is neglected. The parameters chosen for estimation are ln k3(T5), ln 1C1(T5) and E3, with base temperature T5 = 769.26 K (925 F). Reaction rates are expressed in mol/sec/(cm of particle), partial pressures in bar, and energies in ki/mol.

caption_text: The Krane model conforms to Table I except that it uses bulk fluid states, and power functions of p rather than the adsorption function r. The full model in Table 1 proved to be overparametrized for the present data set, but the function r converged rapidly to unity when modelled with a single adsorption term; therefore, results are given only for the version with r = 1. Each model in Table 2 was coded with 12 chemical parameters.
raw_window: The Krane model conforms to Table I except that it uses bulk fluid states, and power functions of p rather than the adsorption function r.

The full model in Table 1 proved to be overparametrized for the present data set, but the function r converged rapidly to unity when modelled with a single adsorption term; therefore, results are given only for the version with r = 1.
Each model in Table 2 was coded with 12 chemical parameters.
